title: Is it right for parents to look through their 15-year-old’s diary just because they want to? - Quora

response.answer_text: I am a 15 year old girl, and I write diaries. I write it on an app in my phone. So recently, my mum wanted to read my diary. ”No,” I said. ”Why not? I’m your mother.” ”It’s private. I wouldn’t want anyone to read my diary. It isn’t anything personal to you, but I just feel this way.” She kept on insisting. “Why can’t you tell me everything? What are you hiding from me? What do you do behind my back?” Oh, nothing much. Just surf the web for porn, read erotic novels, have sex with my 22 year old boyfriend. My diary’s full of my wild adventures to Neverland. “I don’t do anything behind your back. It’s just… it’s just private.” It’s me. It’s my life. I know you gave birth to me, but I would like to be the owner of my soul. And the thing where I express it. She wouldn’t give it up. Eventually, she told me that if I didn’t let her read my diary, then she wouldn’t read anything written by me. I said “Alright,” without thinking anything of it. For the past few months, I wrote novels and short stories that got me a lot of praise from my internet readers and friends and relatives. I entered a contest and got a medal for the best essay. Everyone told me I would be a great writer someday. And my mum didn’t read any of it. Now, this was really hurtful for me. If you’re a writer, imagine one of your most loved person and biggest cheerleader just refusing to acknowledge a story you’ve written with hardship, just turning her face away from the manuscript. It hurts a lot. Especially, when people would ask her about my writings, she would say it out loud, “oh, she doesn’t let me read all her works, so I don’t read anything at all.” ouch. Eventually, I confronted her about it. I shouldn’t have, maybe, because then she told me she would take away my phone and not let me continue my diary at all. I told her I would let her read one entry, if that would make her happy. She said, OK, but she would get to choose which one. I said, no. She persisted on her previous threat. Then I told her, “I would rather delete my works than let you read it.” She told me, “Be my guest.” The next day I deleted my Diary account. Then I cried for hours. Let me tell you this: it’s not like I had any inappropriate things in my diary. I hadn’t done any things I wrote above in italic. There were things I wouldn’t want my mother to read, but they were little things like me knowing the passcode to her phone or going over to my friend’s house to surf on the web when I’m not supposed to (I have got serious curfews regarding the web in my house. I can’t use net in my own phone without permission). But overall, I was just shy about all the feelings and dream I recorded there. And I knew my mother. I knew when she would read what I wrote about feeling depressed and wishing things were different sometimes, she would just scoff out loud, telling me I had a better life than a lot of people. I didn’t want to hear those words. I didn’t want her judgement. And she also has the habit of talking around. Not with random people, but with relatives. I didn’t want their judgement either. I didn’t want them to think I was whiney girl. Because I wasn’t. During the particular day, I was just feeling whiney. And I deleted the account fearing she would find a way to read it somehow. Because she did it once, when I wrote in a notebook, which forced me to move over to one of those secret diary apps with passcode. I really didn’t want it to be deja vu. Maybe you’re not like my mother. Maybe you won’t scoff or talk around. Maybe you won’t stop reading your child’s novels and short stories. But if he doesn’t want you to read the journal, please don’t read it. Will you want someone to be in your head, reading all your thoughts? Maybe you’re not thinking anything harmful or inappropriate, but still, would you want it? Don’t you feel uncomfortable when the coppers in airports or secure places check your body for anything suspicious despite the fact you’re not carrying any explosives? Diary’s like someone’s thoughts on paper. So if he doesn’t want you to read it, don’t read it. Certainly, don’t go snooping around, because that will ruin his trust on you. I don’t trust my mother anymore. I hide a lot of things from her, things I don’t really need to hide from her. But I still hide them. You don’t want your fifteen year old to become like that, trust me. Edit: Many people are accusing my mother of being a terrible person. I just want to say even though what she did was bad, my mum isn't awful. I wouldn’t trade her for anyone else. She's always been supportive and my biggest cheerleader. She's taught me to think and grow the willpower to do what I want. I love my mum and I know she loves me as well. However, no one is a perfect parent. My mum has always wanted me to be open with her - so I suppose she was hurt when I refused to show her my diary. She also grew up in a household where she had no privacy. Therefore, she never understood the need of it and I think she can't believe anyone else could feel different. Like I said, no-one's perfect, so she took the situation way too far and this is what happened. I don't hold it against her anymore, I've forgiven her; but some damage was done. We've always had trust issues and I don't feel the thrill of showing my writings to her anymore. I wrote this answer with a view to make sure no mother had to face this situation with her child again. Another thing: when I said I had sex with my 22 year old boyfriend, I WAS BEING SARCASTIC. I've received a few comments telling me this was rape and I should check myself out blah blah blah. While I appreciate your concern, I'm also a little annoyed that you didn't read my answer properly. I had mentioned in my answer that I hadn’t done any of the stuff written in italics. If you don't believe me… seriously, think about it. You already know what sort of control freak my mother is. Do you really I could do a thing like that behind her back? Also, thanks to everyone for all the upvotes and comments. Edit 2: Some of you wanted to read my short stories. I posted them at the comment, but thought it better to post them here later on. There is one I wrote as a Quora answer: Nazaha Izdihar's answer to Can you share with us a short story written by you? You can read another one. This is in Doc file. Nazaha's elegant egypt work - Nazaha Amatullah I wrote this at 13, so it’s not really my best work. But this was my first hit short story in English!

No, It’s never right and it’s never okay. i read it as someone asking “hey, can parents invades their child’s privacy just because?” no. absolutely not. Read this as you want because I’m 15 too but if your parents cannot trust you even though you haven’t done anything to set off any kind of alarm it’s… disturbing. i have a diary and i am very fortunate to have parents that see it as that. A diary. A very private space of my thoughts, feelings and emotions. you might role your eyes at this but honestly, teenagers hides a storm in their calm outsides. They might have partner that they don’t want you to know about (and if that partner is an adult, honestly, it’s a concern), they might be apart of the LGBTQ+ community but didn’t want to tell you just yet, they might be struggling in school, they might be bullied. there are so many “might” and “maybe” but honestly, it’s not worth losing trust with your kid. even if you are just trying to “help”, if this is your definition of “helping”, get ready to be cut off from their life by the time they become an adult or by the time they got married. By then you have nothing to blame but yourself ad your past actions. your kids always remembers and will always remember your biggest mistakes, reading something very personal and PRIVATE can be one of them. My advice / thought is: if you are the parentDON’T. honestly. it’s not worth it, losing the trust of your kid is not worth it. if you are concern about their mental health, the way they are treated at school or if they are being different recently, you can talk to them but never raise your voice. put them in a space where it is okay to express their feelings, thoughts and emotionsDON’T. if you want to snoop in “just because you want to”, think as if it you are on their shoes. if you can’t do that, think of it like.. if your kid go through your phone and look up every single one of your text, your emails, etc. how would you feel?If you think of it just as “they are my kids, i should be allowed to do that.” GET YOUR NARCISSISTIC, HELICOPTER PARENT ASS AWAY FROM EVERYONE. you disgust me. who do you think you are? their god? they have rights too you idiot. they have their own thoughts and feelings and shit to deal with. stop seeing them just as an extension from yourself and stop being narcissistic. parents like you ruin your kid CONFIDENCE, MENTAL HEALTH and STUMP THEIR GROWTH AS AN OVERALL CAPABLE HUMAN BEING.built a trusting relationship with your kid. show them that you are WORTHY of their trust. (that include not snooping around at their things)if you are the teenI'm very sorry, my best advice to talk to your parents and tell them why it’s not okay, sometimes our parents needs a wakeup call and you need to tell them that you have rights too, you are a human too and you are valid.talk to them about your concerns and feelings, if they are the type to overreact, tell them that. tell them about your concerns and built a trust with them.if they are the helicopter style parent.. honestly.. cut them off as soon as you can, they are stunting your growth as a capable adult. if you want, you can read about articles surrounding helicopter parenting and TALK TO YOUR PARENTS ABOUT IT. again, parents are complicated, especially parents like this. if they are still being a narcissistic ass bitch… cut them off as soon as you can.best wishes to you, i hope your family is doing well <3
